author: Staff Reporter
text:
Even as the Central Government has not released the funds requested by the Union Territory, the Government has been going ahead by disbursing rain relief and assistance to farmers and other sections who had suffered damages in the recent rains, Chief Minister N. Rangasamy has said.

Speaking at a tea party hosted by the Department of Information and Publicity for freedom fighters on the occasion of Republic Day here on Monday, he said that the Government had disbursed rain relief to farmers and most of the cardholders in Puducherry and Karaikal regions.

Mr. Rangasamy said that he had been writing to the Centre seeking enhancement of payment of pension for freedom fighters in the Union Territory. “I hope that a good decision would be available soon,” he said.

Govt. filling vacancies in departments

The Government has been keen about filling vacancies in all line departments. As many as 7,000 vacancies have been filled so far which included around 588 posts of Upper Division Clerk, 768 posts in the Police department and 488 posts of Teachers.

The vacant posts of Pre-primary school teachers would be filled up shortly, he said.

The Government has allotted 78 acres of land to Jawaharlal Institute of Postgraduate Medical Education and Research (JIPMER) in Karaikal. The admission of students is expected to commence from July this year, he added.
title: Freedom fighters, ryots receive rain relief
